awd_titl_txt: Radiation and Transport in QCD Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
A few micro-seconds after the Big Bang the universe was filled with an extremely hot plasma made of elementary particles, the quarks and gluons. When the expanding plasma  cooled to a temperature of about two trillion degrees, quarks and gluons condensed into massive bound states called hadrons, including the protons and neutrons which make up the atomic nuclei of the matter around us. This transition generated over 95% of the visible mass in the universe, and it permanently confined quarks and gluons into hadrons. How these phenomena emerge from the strong nuclear force between quarks and gluons is a forefront question in modern science. High-energy collisions of heavy nuclei provide a unique opportunity to recreate, for a short moment, the primordial medium of the Big Bang in the laboratory. It is a formidable challenge to infer the properties of this medium from its decay products observed in large detectors. The PI will develop theoretical tools to diagnose this matter and rigorously interpret the experimental data. The PI will continue to build a thriving graduate research program and foster scientific outreach to regional high school students through the Saturday Morning Physics program. 

This project aims at quantifying fundamental transport properties of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) and how hadron masses emerge in the quark-to-hadron transition. The transport of heavy quarks through the QGP will be evaluated using innovative quantum many-body techniques, where the heavy-quark interactions will be based on first-principles computations of lattice discretized Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the fundamental theory of the strong interaction. The resulting heavy-quark transport coefficients will be implemented into state-of-the-art simulations of the fireballs formed in heavy-ion collisions. In addition, electromagnetic radiation from these fireballs will be calculated to determine: (a) the temperature of the medium, and (b) how the masses of hadrons emerge as the QGP cools down. Current and future experimental programs at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider and Large Hadron Collider have a large emphasis on heavy-quark and electromagnetic observables. The advances achieved through this project will provide the theoretical rigor and accuracy required to convert systematic comparisons to precision data into robust knowledge about the primordial QCD medium.

por.por_cntn:
Unraveling the mechanism of the ``confinement" of the fundamental quark and gluon particles into bound states called hadrons (such as the nucleons within atomic nuclei) remains one of the major goals in contemporary physics. The theory of the strong nuclear force, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), predicts that at high temperatures hadrons dissolve into a deconfined plasma of quarks and gluons. By colliding atomic nuclei at very high energies at large accelerator facilities, one is able to create matter at the highest temperatures ever reached by mankind, in excess of two trillion degrees Kelvin. This kind of matter, to the best of our knowledge, last existed in the first few microseconds of our universe. To investigate the formation and properties of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) and its confinement back into hadrons in heavy-ion collisions, suitable probes that can be measured in these experiments are required.

In this project, the PI and his research group have conducted theoretical studies aimed at a deeper understanding of QCD matter and its signatures in heavy-ion experiments. In particular, they have developed a theoretical framework to utilize the heavy charm and bottom quarks to probe the transport and hadronization properties of the QGP. The masses of charm and bottom quarks are much larger than the typical temperatures of the mini-fireballs produced in the heavy-ion collisions. Therefore, the diffusion of heavy quarks through the QGP is akin to a "Brownian" motion, whereby the changes in their momentum spectra in heavy-ion collisions are directly calculable from the transport parameters of the diffusion equation. The PI and his group have developed a quantum many-body approach to describe the interactions of the heavy quarks in the QGP and their transition into heavy hadrons. These developments have been instrumental in extracting the transport coefficient from numerical simulations of heavy-quark diffusion and their comparison to experimental data. The diffusion coefficient turns out to be close to the lower bound allowed by quantum mechanics, requiring extremely large collision rates of the heavy quarks in the QGP. Moreover, the effective interactions employed in these calculations reveal that remnants of the long-range confining force survive in the QGP at moderate temperatures. This force component has been identified as the key agent to render the QGP a strongly coupled quantum liquid. When deploying this formalism to evaluate the spectral properties of the QGP, the collision rates of the thermal light quarks and gluons close to the transition temperature turn out to be so high that the quantum-mechanical uncertainty principle wipes out their spectral lines in the energy spectra. Instead, the confining force drives the emergence of bound states that gradually become the dominant degrees of freedom, thus catalyzing the transition to confined hadronic matter.

The PI's research in this project led to about 30 publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. This project further encompassed an integrated education, research and outreach activity. The Saturday Morning Physics program at Texas A&M, directed by the PI and 2 colleagues, offered first-hand lectures by faculty members on forefront research topics, attracting 50-100 regional high-school students on any of seven Saturdays in the '18 and '19 spring semesters, with a near 50% participation of underrepresented groups. The PI mentored five undergraduate-student research projects, including the NSF's Research Experience for Undergraduate program at Texas A&M's Cyclotron Institute. Three of the PI's graduate students completed their PhD degree in theoretical nuclear physics; they all moved on to academic appointments.
